newsitem.title: UK: Shell targets $1 bln profit in new upstream ventures.
newsitem.headline: Shell targets $1 bln profit in new upstream ventures.

text.p: Shell's upstream business development wing hopes to add some $1 billion to group profits through new oil and gas projects to be developed by 2001, company sources said on Monday.
Royal Dutch Shell Group's development company, Shell EP International Ventures, set the target as part of a five-year business plan adopted in early 1996, sources said.

"Naturally we are hoping the actual values are much, much higher than that," said a company source. "Its booked as 'added value' when we commit to a deal and hand it over to the production people to manage."
The extra revenue will all come from areas where Shell was not previously producing hydrocarbons, the source stressed.
Projects were currently being assessed in 40 countries world-wide and two deals have already been struck under the business plan, he said.
In April Shell took a quarter of Cairn Energy PLC'a interests in Bangladesh, which included an 18.75 percent stake in the 800 billion cubic feet Sangu gas field.
The company was now exploring markets for the gas in Bangladesh and neighbouring India, the source said.
It has also taken a small stake in the Caspian Pipeline Consortium building a 1,500 km (940 mile) oil pipeline from Kazakhstan's Tengiz oilfield to Russia's Black Sea port of Novorossisk.
Shell EP International Ventures reorganised itself last year to make itself more efficient in developing markets for new exploration finds, the source said.

The new approach centred on better exploiting cutting-edge deep water technology, finding markets for gas reserves, securing openings in politically uncertain regions and clearing bottlenecks in the development process, he said.
